{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3488474,"name":"Anthony","username":"anthv","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/9de053/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T21:50:58.156Z","cooked":"

Our team is using the CTRE generated Swerve drive for the first time. Normal drive is working fine but our driver prefers to use the right joystick to set the angle instead of rotating.

We’ve tried to use the FieldCentricFacingAngle swerve method but are having issues with it rotating correctly and maintaining that position. Does anyone have any example code they’d be willing to share to help point us in the right direction?

Appreciate any help given!

I have some code here that would snap to angle based on which way the D-pad was pressed here. You can modify it by taking in joystick x and y to get which angle it should point towards. It’s not that clean of code cause I wrote it in between classes lol.

Edit: The code below is a lot better. Use that.

Here’s what I did last year:

(Setup)

    private final SwerveRequest.FieldCentricFacingAngle snapDrive = new SwerveRequest.FieldCentricFacingAngle()
            .withDeadband(MAX_SPEED * 0.035)
            .withDriveRequestType(DriveRequestType.Velocity);

You’ll need to initialize and set up a PhoenixPIDController. If you’re not getting an aggressive enough snap, up the P.

snapDrive.HeadingController = new PhoenixPIDController(10, 0., 0.);
snapDrive.HeadingController.enableContinuousInput(-Math.PI, Math.PI);

And applying it:

drivetrain.applyRequest(() -> snapDrive
                .withVelocityX(getXSpeed(true))
                .withVelocityY(getYSpeed(true))
                .withTargetDirection(Rotation2d.fromDegrees(direction.Angle)))

With direction being an Enum defining forward, left, right etc. and the Angle being a degree value.

This was pretty helpful, and got me to the answer. Leaving this here for the next soul trying to solve this.
Ultimately, here is how I ended up achieving this, with Phoenix 6-2025.

    private final SwerveRequest.FieldCentricFacingAngle snapDrive = new SwerveRequest.FieldCentricFacingAngle()
        .withHeadingPID(7.0,0.0,0.0)
        .withDeadband(MaxSpeed * 0.035)
        .withDriveRequestType(DriveRequestType.OpenLoopVoltage);

Note that initializing the PhoenixPIDController and setting it to continuous input was not required, it was all handled in the “.withHeadingPID” decorator on the request.
